com.gnahraf.io.store.table.order

Class RowOrder

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gnahraf.util.ClassEquivalent
      • com.gnahraf.io.store.table.order.RowOrder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparator<ByteBuffer>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CompoundOrder, LexicalRowOrder, RowOrderAtOffset

    public abstract class RowOrder
extends ClassEquivalent
implements Comparator<ByteBuffer>
    Defines an ordering over rows.

    Importance of Equality Semantics

    Elsewhere the code makes a best effort to guard against mixing incompatible row orderings. This compatibility is tested with the RowOrder.equals(..) method. It's important, therefore, that subclasses have reasonable equality semantics. The default behavior by the base class is to treat all instances of the same class equivalent.
    Author:
    Babak
    See Also:
    RowOrders

    • Method Detail

      • compareRows

        public abstract int compareRows(ByteBuffer rowA,
              ByteBuffer rowB)
        Compares two rows. The two rows are assumed to be non null. This is a read-only operation: the implementation shall not ever modify the state of its input arguments; modifying then restoring the position and limits is not permissible.

        Note, one of the input arguments may be a key, in which case the implementation may allow the key to have a different length than the row.

        Returns:
        the return value has the same semantics as Comparator.compare(Object, Object)

      • compare

        public final int compare(ByteBuffer rowA,
          ByteBuffer rowB)
        Synonym for compareRows(ByteBuffer, ByteBuffer).
        Specified by:
        compare in interface Comparator<ByteBuffer>

      • isRelative

        public abstract boolean isRelative()
        Indicates whether the implementation considers an input ByteBuffer's position (and possibly limit) when comparing it to another.
        Returns:
        true, if an input buffer's position matters in comparisons

      • isAbsolute

        public final boolean isAbsolute()
        The opposite of isRelative().
